summary: This is a Bureau of Prisons (BOP) annual training instructor guide for suicide prevention in fiscal year 2019. It provides statistics on inmate suicides, identifies high-risk groups (including sex offenders), outlines risk factors and warning signs, and details staff responsibilities and intervention procedures. This document is a 2019 Bureau of Prisons (BOP) annual training presentation on suicide prevention for correctional staff. It covers risk factors, warning signs, staff responsibilities, and procedures for managing suicidal inmates, including the use of suicide watch rooms and inmate observers. It references reviewing actual inmate suicides from Fiscal Year 2018 as case studies.

events.title: Inmate Suicides in Fiscal Year 2018
events.description: There were 28 inmate suicides in the BOP in FY2018, with a rate of 15 per 100,000. 39% involved inmates with a conviction or charge for a sex offense, a significant increase from 2017.

events.title: Sex Offender Suicide Rate
events.description: In fiscal year 2014, sex offenders made up 41% of inmates who completed suicide in the BOP.

events.title: Review of FY2018 Inmate Suicides
events.description: The presentation instructs the presenter to review 2-5 inmate suicides from the Fiscal Year 2018 roster as case studies to help staff identify risk factors and warning signs.

keyFacts: In FY2018, 39% of BOP inmate suicides involved individuals with a conviction or charge for a sex offense, a significant increase from 26% in 2017.
Sex offenders are identified as one of four high-risk groups for suicide in the BOP, with risk highest at the beginning of their sentence or upon transfer.
The overall inmate suicide rate in FY2018 was 15 per 100,000, which is significantly higher than the previous year and most similar to the rate in 1995.
A disproportionate number of inmate suicides occur in restrictive housing (like SHU) or while in a single cell, with hanging being the most frequently chosen method.
The training emphasizes that staff, regardless of job specialty, have a responsibility to monitor inmates and report concerns about potential suicidal behavior to psychology or medical staff.
This is a standard BOP suicide prevention training module from 2019, not a case-specific document about Jeffrey Epstein.
The training details procedures for suicide watch, including the potential use of trained 'inmate observers' and 'inmate companions' to monitor at-risk inmates.
It references reviewing actual inmate suicide cases from Fiscal Year 2018 to train staff on identifying risk factors.
The document emphasizes staff responsibilities: recognize warning signs, communicate empathy, respond correctly, and follow up on monitored inmates.
It states that only the Suicide Prevention Program Coordinator or designee has the authority to terminate a suicide watch once it has begun.
